pr_title: ENH: ability to dynamically update efSearch setting

timeline.message: add ef_search into query and query builder; adapt loadIndex
Adapt test case to cover efsearch in query
FIX: validity check and test case

timeline.body:
This method would be called only once when there is cache miss. The ```efsearch``` value passed is stored in the 
[IndexWrapper](https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/blob/master/jni/src/com_amazon_opendistroforelasticsearch_knn_index_v1736_KNNIndex.cpp#L49) as part of [init](https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/blob/master/jni/src/com_amazon_opendistroforelasticsearch_knn_index_v1736_KNNIndex.cpp#L204) call. So ef_search passed in subsequent queries would not be reflected. 

Ideal way is to plumb the ef_search through [queryIndex](https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/blob/master/src/main/java/com/amazon/opendistroforelasticsearch/knn/index/v1736/KNNIndex.java#L71) function from [KNNWeight](https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/blob/master/src/main/java/com/amazon/opendistroforelasticsearch/knn/index/KNNWeight.java#L101). As part of this function in the [jni](https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/blob/master/jni/src/com_amazon_opendistroforelasticsearch_knn_index_v1736_KNNIndex.cpp#L147), we could set the  ```ef_search``` using```setQueryTimeParams``` if ```ef_search``` is not null otherwise just use the existing value. 

We need to be careful while calling ```setQueryTimeParams``` because at the same time it is possible some query is already referencing this object and could cause segmentation faults. We need to kind of ensure only one thread is setting/getting ```ef_search``` .
timeline.bodyText:
This method would be called only once when there is cache miss. The efsearch value passed is stored in the
IndexWrapper as part of init call. So ef_search passed in subsequent queries would not be reflected.
Ideal way is to plumb the ef_search through queryIndex function from KNNWeight. As part of this function in the jni, we could set the  ef_search usingsetQueryTimeParams if ef_search is not null otherwise just use the existing value.
We need to be careful while calling setQueryTimeParams because at the same time it is possible some query is already referencing this object and could cause segmentation faults. We need to kind of ensure only one thread is setting/getting ef_search .
timeline.bodyHTML:
This method would be called only once when there is cache miss. The efsearch value passed is stored in the
IndexWrapper as part of init call. So ef_search passed in subsequent queries would not be reflected.

Ideal way is to plumb the ef_search through queryIndex function from KNNWeight. As part of this function in the jni, we could set the ef_search usingsetQueryTimeParams if ef_search is not null otherwise just use the existing value.

We need to be careful while calling setQueryTimeParams because at the same time it is possible some query is already referencing this object and could cause segmentation faults. We need to kind of ensure only one thread is setting/getting ef_search .
timeline.author: vamshin

@@ -273,11 +275,12 @@ public void evictAllGraphsFromCache() {
      *
      * @param indexPathUrl path for serialized hnsw graph
      * @param indexName index name
+     * @param efSearch HNSW parameter that represents "the size of the dynamic list for the nearest neighbors"

      * to Resource watcher or if the JNI call throws

-    public KNNIndexCacheEntry loadIndex(String indexPathUrl, String indexName) throws Exception {
+    public KNNIndexCacheEntry loadIndex(String indexPathUrl, String indexName, int efSearch) throws Exception {

replies.bodyText:
Ideal way is to plumb the ef_search through queryIndex function from KNNWeight. As part of this function in the jni, we could set the ef_search using setQueryTimeParams if ef_search is not null otherwise just use the existing value.

Thanks for pointing that out. I need to renew license on CLion for getting this part done.

We need to be careful while calling setQueryTimeParams because at the same time it is possible some query is already referencing this object and could cause segmentation faults. We need to kind of ensure only one thread is setting/getting ef_search .

Thanks for reminder. My first thought is to use writeLock in queryIndex if ef_search is not null. Might need to put some thought into this. Suggestion is welcome.
replies.author: chenqi0805

replies.bodyText:
I suspect that supporting a dynamic efSearch parameter would either require:

Synchronizing search queries from multiple threads onto a shared index (which would likely hurt query performance significantly)
Require changes to the KNN library dependency to make the efSearch parameter a local parameter of the KNN query structure rather than a member of the index. It's currently a class member of the HNSW index, which is why the opendistro plugin is setting it once on index load rather than supporting per query, since mutations within queries would affect unrelated queries (see here for one example usage of the member variable).
replies.author: jschmitz28

replies.bodyText:
Agree. Synchronizing could hurt performance because of locking. At this point to me, Approach 2 mentioned by @jschmitz28  seems to be best way to achieve this.
Other solution i could think of is, make ef_search setting dynamic Elasticsearch index setting(currently its static index setting, once define cannot be changed). On the change of this setting, we could evict the graphs from memory and load freshly with the new ef_search.  We already do this eviction when we change few settings. Example here

This removes the indexing cost to rebuild the whole index which is a pain point today and on next query graphs should be available for search.
Avoid errors possible from mutation.
replies.author: vamshin

replies.bodyText:
@vamshin I have two more points to clarify regarding your solution, first UX and second implementation:
(1) dynamical setting still needs to be updated through index settings API: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-update-settings.html
so I think UX is going to be different from #116 . Is that OK? Otherwise I will return to approach 2 by @jschmitz28 .
(2) On trying to implemnt your solution by defining ef_search to be index scope and dynamic. As you mentioned, we also need to add custom setting update consumer for that ef_search. Now the issue is that IndexModule has not yet been passed into KNNSettings so we do not have way to add the consumer for index scope settings.
From my observation, we can implement
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/853dd1b873d02d04231c32722d4784c9da1068dc/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/plugins/Plugin.java#L131
in KNNPlugin, then we add an accept index module API in KNNSetting. Thought?
replies.author: chenqi0805

replies.bodyText:
@chenqi0805
(1) Seems to be perfectly ok to change that.
Regarding the approach mentioned by @jschmitz28  we could create an issue in the nmslib and ask their opinion about this change? Not sure if they had to do this way for some optimizations.
(2) Makes sense.
replies.author: vamshin

timeline.body: We do not have to change this method.  This method can always read the default setting so that ```IndexWrapper``` can refer it when ```ef_search``` is null.

timeline.body: rebuild whole cache might not be necessary as we could lose graphs of other indices. Once we have the clear cache api https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/k-NN/issues/68 , we could selectively evict entries of a particular index. We could leave a ```TODO```  to fix after clear cache api is built. Would be great to create an issue as well to just track the fix?

timeline.message: TST: cache miss for search after update setting

timeline.body:
I think the purpose of this test case is to confirm that the Index is evicted from the cache after the settings are updated. That being said, I think the test should be renamed `testCacheRebuiltAfterUpdateIndexSettings`.

Further more, instead of comparing deltas of hit and miss count, you can check that the cache is empty with the `indices_in_cache` stat. Then, you can just
1. Create index
2. Index sample docs
3. Search index
4. Confirm index is present in cache
5. Update index settings
6. Confirm there are no indices in the cache.
timeline.bodyText:
I think the purpose of this test case is to confirm that the Index is evicted from the cache after the settings are updated. That being said, I think the test should be renamed testCacheRebuiltAfterUpdateIndexSettings.
Further more, instead of comparing deltas of hit and miss count, you can check that the cache is empty with the indices_in_cache stat. Then, you can just

Create index
Index sample docs
Search index
Confirm index is present in cache
Update index settings
Confirm there are no indices in the cache.
timeline.bodyHTML:
I think the purpose of this test case is to confirm that the Index is evicted from the cache after the settings are updated. That being said, I think the test should be renamed testCacheRebuiltAfterUpdateIndexSettings.

Further more, instead of comparing deltas of hit and miss count, you can check that the cache is empty with the indices_in_cache stat. Then, you can just

  1. Create index
  2. Index sample docs
  3. Search index
  4. Confirm index is present in cache
  5. Update index settings
  6. Confirm there are no indices in the cache.
timeline.author: jmazanec15
